Arzelà-Ascoli, Banach-Steinhaus

  1. Define what it means to say that fn→ff_n \to ffn​→f weakly in L2([0,1])L^2\p{\br{0,1}}L2([0,1]).

  2. Suppose fn∈L2([0,1])f_n \in L^2\p{\br{0,1}}fn​∈L2([0,1]) converge weakly to f∈L2([0,1])f \in L^2\p{\br{0,1}}f∈L2([0,1]) and define primitive functions:

    Fn(x)=∫0xfn(t) dtandF(x)=∫0xf(t) dt.F_n\p{x} = \int_0^x f_n\p{t} \,\diff{t} \quad\text{and}\quad F\p{x} = \int_0^x f\p{t} \,\diff{t}.Fn​(x)=∫0x​fn​(t)dtandF(x)=∫0x​f(t)dt.

    Show that Fn,F∈C([0,1])F_n, F \in C\p{\br{0,1}}Fn​,F∈C([0,1]) and that Fn→FF_n \to FFn​→F uniformly on [0,1]\br{0, 1}[0,1].
Solution.

  1. fn→ff_n \to ffn​→f weakly in L2([0,1])L^2\p{\br{0,1}}L2([0,1]) if for every g∈L2([0,1])g \in L^2\p{\br{0,1}}g∈L2([0,1]), we have

    ∫fng dt→n→∞∫fg dt.\int f_ng \,\diff{t} \xrightarrow{n\to\infty} \int fg \,\diff{t}.∫fn​gdtn→∞​∫fgdt.

  2. Notice that by weak convergence, sup⁡n∣⟨fn,g⟩∣<∞\sup_n \abs{\inner{f_n, g}} < \inftysupn​∣⟨fn​,g⟩∣<∞ for any g∈L2([0,1])g \in L^2\p{\br{0,1}}g∈L2([0,1]). L2([0,1])L^2\p{\br{0,1}}L2([0,1]) is its own dual, we may view {fn}n⊆(L2([0,1]))∗\set{f_n}_n \subseteq \p{L^2\p{\br{0,1}}}^*{fn​}n​⊆(L2([0,1]))∗ and so by the uniform boundedness principle,

    sup⁡n ∣⟨fn,g⟩∣<∞∀g∈L2([0,1])  ⟹  M≔sup⁡n ∥fn∥L2<∞.\sup_n\, \abs{\inner{f_n, g}} < \infty \quad \forall g \in L^2\p{\br{0,1}} \implies M \coloneqq \sup_n\,\norm{f_n}_{L^2} < \infty.nsup​∣⟨fn​,g⟩∣<∞∀g∈L2([0,1])⟹M:=nsup​∥fn​∥L2​<∞.

    Thus for x0∈[0,1]x_0 \in \br{0, 1}x0​∈[0,1], Cauchy-Schwarz gives

    ∣Fn(x)−Fn(x0)∣≤∣∫xx0fn(t) dt∣≤∥χ[x,x0]∥L2∥fn∥L2≤M∣x−x0∣1/2→x→x00.\abs{F_n\p{x} - F_n\p{x_0}} \leq \abs{\int_x^{x_0} f_n\p{t} \,\diff{t}} \leq \norm{\chi_{\br{x,x_0}}}_{L^2}\norm{f_n}_{L^2} \leq M\abs{x - x_0}^{1/2} \xrightarrow{x\to x_0} 0.∣Fn​(x)−Fn​(x0​)∣≤∣∣​∫xx0​​fn​(t)dt∣∣​≤∥∥​χ[x,x0​]​∥∥​L2​∥fn​∥L2​≤M∣x−x0​∣1/2x→x0​​0.

    Notice that the upper bound is uniform over n≥1n \geq 1n≥1, so {Fn}n\set{F_n}_n{Fn​}n​ is actually equicontinuous. Similarly,

    ∣Fn(x)∣≤∫01∣fn(t)∣ dt≤∥fn∥L2≤M,\abs{F_n\p{x}} \leq \int_0^1 \abs{f_n\p{t}} \,\diff{t} \leq \norm{f_n}_{L^2} \leq M,∣Fn​(x)∣≤∫01​∣fn​(t)∣dt≤∥fn​∥L2​≤M,

    so {Fn}n\set{F_n}_n{Fn​}n​ is uniformly bounded. By Arzelà-Ascoli, {Fn}n\set{F_n}_n{Fn​}n​ admits a uniformly convergent subsequence. Moreover, since χ[0,x]∈L2([0,1])\chi_{\br{0,x}} \in L^2\p{\br{0,1}}χ[0,x]​∈L2([0,1]), weak convergence also implies

    Fn(x)=∫fn(t)χ[0,x](t) dt→n→∞∫f(t)χ[0,x](t) dt=F(x).F_n\p{x} = \int f_n\p{t} \chi_{\br{0,x}}\p{t} \,\diff{t} \xrightarrow{n\to\infty} \int f\p{t} \chi_{\br{0,x}}\p{t} \,\diff{t} = F\p{x}.Fn​(x)=∫fn​(t)χ[0,x]​(t)dtn→∞​∫f(t)χ[0,x]​(t)dt=F(x).

    Thus, any convergent subsequence of {Fn}n\set{F_n}_n{Fn​}n​ must converge to FFF. This implies that Fn→FF_n \to FFn​→F uniformly itself. Otherwise, there exists ε>0\epsilon > 0ε>0 such that there exists xn1∈[0,1]x_{n_1} \in \br{0, 1}xn1​​∈[0,1] with ∣Fn1(xn1)−F(xn1)∣≥ε\abs{F_{n_1}\p{x_{n_1}} - F\p{x_{n_1}}} \geq \epsilon∣Fn1​​(xn1​​)−F(xn1​​)∣≥ε. By induction, we get a subsequence nkn_knk​ such that ∣Fnk(xnk)−F(xnk)∣≥ε\abs{F_{n_k}\p{x_{n_k}} - F\p{x_{n_k}}} \geq \epsilon∣Fnk​​(xnk​​)−F(xnk​​)∣≥ε for all k≥1k \geq 1k≥1, so no subsequence of {Fnk}k\set{F_{n_k}}_k{Fnk​​}k​ may converge uniformly to FFF. But by Arzelà-Ascoli, {Fnk}k\set{F_{n_k}}_k{Fnk​​}k​ must admit a uniformly convergent subsequence to FFF, a contradiction. Hence, Fn→FF_n \to FFn​→F uniformly to begin with, which completes the proof.
